steps.title: Read the article once without writing anything down.
steps.content: Read the article once without writing anything down. The first reading should be used to learn concepts and gain a general grasp of the content. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Look up any terms or words that you are unclear about.
steps.content: Look up any terms or words that you are unclear about. If your article is technical, you should ensure you understand all the concepts before you begin to analyze. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Write a short three to four sentence summary of the article.
steps.content: Write a short three to four sentence summary of the article. If you are unable to do so, you may need to reread it for content.

steps.title: Consider explaining the article aloud if that is easier than writing.
steps.content: Consider explaining the article aloud if that is easier than writing. If you can explain the outline and content of the article in non-technical language, you are ready to move on. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Make a photocopy of the article.
steps.content: Make a photocopy of the article. You can also print out a copy. Unless you are very familiar with a note taking program like Evernote, you should do it by hand. Ensure you have page numbers, so that you can cite the article correctly in your analysis.

steps.title: Read the article a second time to underscore thematic concepts.
steps.content: Read the article a second time to underscore thematic concepts. You will want to read more slowly and mark in the margins as you go. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Highlight the thesis of the article.
steps.content: Highlight the thesis of the article. This should be the main argument that the writer is making or trying to prove. Your analysis will refer back to this thesis frequently as you decide how successful the author was in convincing their audience. [5] X Trustworthy Source Purdue Online Writing Lab Trusted resource for writing and citation guidelines Go to source

steps.title: Underline concepts that recur frequently throughout the article.
steps.content: Underline concepts that recur frequently throughout the article. Underline supporting points and make notes about them in the margins as you go along. [6] X Research source If you are reading a scientific paper, look for methods, evidence, and results. This is the accepted structure of most scientific papers.

steps.title: Make notes of any concepts that are not fully proven or explained.
steps.content: Make notes of any concepts that are not fully proven or explained. These annotations will save you time during the writing process.

steps.title: Write the summary or abstract of the article.
steps.content: Write the summary or abstract of the article. If you are writing an analysis essay, this can serve as your introduction. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Provide some cursory research about the writer of the article.
steps.content: Provide some cursory research about the writer of the article. Their qualifications will prove whether their opinions are part of an area of expertise. In historical articles, this will also establish whether the author is a primary or secondary source. State whether you believe the author could be guilty of a bias. [8] X Research source In media-related articles, you should state whether the author was able to stay somewhat objective as they relayed news to the audience.

steps.title: Establish the audience of the article.
steps.content: Establish the audience of the article. Decide if you believe the author catered well to the audience. For example, if the audience is the general public, but the author uses very technical terms, it may not be a convincing article.

steps.title: Decide the purpose of the article.
steps.content: Decide the purpose of the article. This may also be the thesis, or what the author is trying to prove. The author may propose questions and answer them later. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Answer how successfully the author proves the thesis.
steps.content: Answer how successfully the author proves the thesis. State examples, such as in-text citations, to outline particularly successful or failed arguments. Move through the article establishing how meaningful and cohesive their arguments were. [10] X Research source Refer back to your annotations to find quotations or questions about the validity of an argument.

steps.title: Compare the article to other articles on the same subject.
steps.content: Compare the article to other articles on the same subject. If you have been asked to read more than one article, you can analyze one article in light of another. State which argument was more convincing and why.

steps.title: Write any questions that were left unanswered.
steps.content: Write any questions that were left unanswered. Decide if the author could have improved their article by providing more evidence or in-depth research on a topic.

steps.title: Explain why the article matters to the reader and to the world in general.
steps.content: Explain why the article matters to the reader and to the world in general. At this point, you should consider stating your opinion about the topic. Some classes ask for the reader's opinions, while others demand a very scientific critique.

steps.title: Create a Works Cited page if you used citations in your article.
steps.content: Create a Works Cited page if you used citations in your article. Ask your teacher what style you should be using, such as MLA, Chicago, or APA. [11] X Research source
